page.title: 01Middleton Moor & Black Rigg
page.content: The block is predominantly rolling heather moorland but with extensive conifer plantation in the west. Keys Rock Road just touches the area so there is vehicular access but other roads are tracks used by forestry workers and not open to the public. There are some footpaths and the remoteness of the area makes it attractive to walkers, but roads are bad so large numbers are visitors are avoided. The moorland has some use as rough grazing for sheep and for grouse shooting. The extreme west touches on the farming area of Harcroft Beek Valley and is used for mainly grazing. The block is uninhabited.
